00001 /*! \file kernel.c
00002  *  \brief
00003  *  This is the main source code for the kernel. Here all important variables
00004  *  will be initialized.
00005  */
00006

00031 executable_table_size=0;

00041 timer_queue_head=-1;

00047 /* Function definitions */

00049 /* The outb and outw functions are used when accessing hardware devices. */
00050 
00051 /*! Wrapper for a byte out instruction. */
00052 inline static void
00053 outb(const short port_number, const char output_value)
00054 {
00055  __asm volatile("outb %%al,%%dx" : : "d" (port_number), "a" (output_value));
00056 }
00057 
00058 /*! Wrapper for a word out instruction. */
00059 inline static void
00060 outw(const short port_number, const short output_value)
00061 {
00062  __asm volatile("outw %%ax,%%dx" : : "d" (port_number), "a" (output_value));
00063 }
00064 
00065 void
00066 kprints(const char* string)
00067 {
00068  /* Loop until we have found the null character. */
00069  while(1)
00070  {
00071   register const char curr = *string++;
00072 
00073   if (curr)
00074   {
00075    outb(0xe9, curr);
00076   }
00077   else
00078   {
00079    return;
00080   }
00081  }
00082 }
00083 
00084 void
00085 kprinthex(const register long value)
00086 {
00087  const static char hex_helper[16]="0123456789abcdef";
00088  register int      i;
00089 
00090  /* Print each character of the hexadecimal number. This is a very inefficient
00091     way of printing hexadecimal numbers. It is, however, very compact in terms
00092     of the number of source code lines. */
00093  for(i=15; i>=0; i--)
00094  {
00095   outb(0xe9, hex_helper[(value>>(i*4))&15]);
00096  }
00097 }
00098 
00099 /*! Helper struct that is used to return values from prepare_process. */
00100 struct prepare_process_return_value
00101 {
00102  unsigned long first_instruction_address
00103   /*!< The address of the first instruction in the prepared process image. */;
00104  unsigned long page_table_address
00105   /*!< The address of the page table tree set up for the process. */;
00106 };
00107 
00108 /*! Copies an ELF image to memory and prepares a process. prepare_process
00109     does some checks to avoid that corrupt images gets copied to memory.
00110     However, the checks are not as thorough as the check in initialize.
00111     \return A prepare_process_return_value struct holding the first address
00112             of the process image and an address to the page table for
00113             the process. */
00114 static struct prepare_process_return_value
00115 prepare_process(const struct Elf64_Ehdr* elf_image
00116                  /*!< Points to the ELF image to copy. */,
00117                 const unsigned int       process
00118                  /*!< The index of the process that is to be created. */,
00119                 unsigned long            memory_footprint_size
00120                  /*!< Holds the maximum amount of memory, in bytes,
00121                       the image is allowed to use. */)
00122 {
00123  /* Get the address of the program header table. */
00124  int                program_header_index;
00125  struct Elf64_Phdr* program_header = ((struct Elf64_Phdr*)
00126                                        (((char*) (elf_image)) +
00127                                         elf_image->e_phoff));
00128  unsigned long      used_memory = 0;
00129 
00130  /* Allocate memory for the page table and for the process' memory. All of
00131     this is allocated in a single memory block. The memory block is set up so
00132     that it cannot be de-allocated via kfree. */
00133  long               address_to_memory_block =
00134   kalloc(memory_footprint_size+19*4*1024, process, ALLOCATE_FLAG_KERNEL);
00135 
00136  struct prepare_process_return_value ret_val = {0, 0};
00137 
00138 
00139  /* First check that we have enough memory. */
00140  if (0 >= address_to_memory_block)
00141  {
00142   /* No, we don't. */
00143   return ret_val;
00144  }
00145 
00146  ret_val.page_table_address = address_to_memory_block;
00147 
00148  {
00149   /* Create a page table for the process. */
00150   unsigned long* dst = (unsigned long*) address_to_memory_block;
00151   unsigned long* src = (unsigned long*) (kernel_page_table_root + 3*4*1024);
00152   register int i;
00153 
00154   /* Clear the first frames. */
00155   for(i=0; i<3*4*1024/8; i++)
00156   {
00157    *dst = 0;
00158   }
00159 
00160   /* Build the pml4 table. */
00161   dst = (unsigned long*) (address_to_memory_block);
00162   *dst = (address_to_memory_block+4096) | 7;
00163 
00164   /* Build the pdp table. */
00165   dst = (unsigned long*) (address_to_memory_block+4096);
00166   *dst = (address_to_memory_block+2*4096) | 7;
00167 
00168   /* Build the pd table. */
00169   dst = (unsigned long*) (address_to_memory_block+2*4096);
00170   for(i=0; i<16; i++)
00171   {
00172    *dst++ = (address_to_memory_block+(3+i)*4096) | 7;
00173   }
00174 
00175   /* Copy the rest of the kernel page table. */
00176   dst = (unsigned long*) (address_to_memory_block + 3*4*1024);
00177   for(i=0; i<(16*1024*4/8); i++)
00178   {
00179    *dst++ = *src++;
00180   }
00181  }
00182 
00183  /* Update the start of the block to be after the page table. */
00184 
00185  address_to_memory_block += 19*4*1024;
00186 
00187  /* Scan through the program header table and copy all PT_LOAD segments to
00188     memory. Perform checks at the same time.*/
00189 
00190  for (program_header_index = 0;
00191       program_header_index < elf_image->e_phnum;
00192       program_header_index++)
00193  {
00194   if (PT_LOAD == program_header[program_header_index].p_type)
00195   {
00196    /* Calculate destination adress. */
00197    unsigned long* dst = (unsigned long *) (address_to_memory_block +
00198                                            used_memory);
00199 
00200    /* Check for odd things. */
00201    if (
00202        /* Check if the segment is contiguous */
00203        (used_memory != program_header[program_header_index].p_vaddr) ||
00204        /* Check if the segmen fits in memory. */
00205        (used_memory + program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz >
00206         memory_footprint_size) ||
00207        /* Check if the segment has an odd size. We require the segment
00208           size to be an even multiple of 8. */
00209        (0 != (program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz&7)) ||
00210        (0 != (program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz&7)))
00211    {
00212     /* Something went wrong. Panic. */
00213     while(1)
00214     {
00215      kprints(
00216 "Kernel panic: Trying to create a process out of a corrupt executable image!");
00217     }
00218    }
00219 
00220    /* First copy p_filesz from the image to memory. */
00221    {
00222     /* Calculate the source address. */
00223     unsigned long* src = (unsigned long *) (((char*) elf_image)+
00224      program_header[program_header_index].p_offset);
00225     unsigned long count = program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz/8;
00226 
00227     for(; count>0; count--)
00228     {
00229      *dst++=*src++;
00230     }
00231    }
00232 
00233 
00234    /* Then write p_memsz-p_filesz bytes of zeros. This to pad the segment. */
00235    {
00236     unsigned long count = (program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz-
00237                            program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz)/8;
00238 
00239     for(; count>0; count--)
00240     {
00241      *dst++=0;
00242     }
00243    }
00244 
00245    /* Set the permission bits on the loaded segment. */
00246    update_memory_protection(ret_val.page_table_address,
00247                             program_header[program_header_index].p_vaddr+
00248                              address_to_memory_block,
00249                             program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz,
00250                             program_header[program_header_index].p_flags&7);
00251 
00252    /* Finally update the amount of used memory. */
00253    used_memory += program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz;
00254   }
00255  }
00256 
00257  /* Find out the address to the first instruction to be executed. */
00258  ret_val.first_instruction_address = address_to_memory_block +
00259                                      elf_image->e_entry;
00260 
00261  return ret_val;
00262 }
00263 
00264 /*! This is the last thing that is run when a process terminates. */
00265 static void
00266 cleanup_process(const int process /*!< The index, into process_table, of the
00267                                        terminating process. */)
00268 {
00269  register unsigned int i;
00270 
00271  for(i=0; i<memory_pages; i++)
00272  {
00273   if (page_frame_table[i].owner == process)
00274   {
00275    page_frame_table[i].owner=-1;
00276    page_frame_table[i].free_is_allowed=1;
00277   }
00278  }
00279 
00280  cpu_private_data.page_table_root = kernel_page_table_root;
00281 }
00282 
00283 void
00284 initialize(void)
00285 {
00286  register int i;
00287 
00288  /* Loop over all threads in the thread table and reset the owner. */
00289  for(i=0; i<MAX_NUMBER_OF_THREADS; i++)
00290  {
00291   thread_table[i].data.owner=-1; /* -1 is an illegal process_table index.
00292                                      We use that to show that the thread
00293                                      is dormant. */
00294  }
00295 
00296  /* Loop over all processes in the thread table and mark them as not
00297     executing. */
00298  for(i=0; i<MAX_NUMBER_OF_PROCESSES; i++)
00299  {
00300   process_table[i].threads=0;    /* No executing process has less than 1
00301                                     thread. */
00302  }
00303 
00304  /* Initialize the ready queue. */
00305  thread_queue_init(&ready_queue);
00306 
00307  /* Calculate the number of pages. */
00308  memory_pages = memory_size/(4*1024);
00309 
00310  {
00311   /* Calculate the number of frames occupied by the kernel and executable
00312      images. */
00313   const register int k=first_available_memory_byte/(4*1024);
00314 
00315   /* Mark the pages that are used by the kernel or executable images as taken
00316     by the kernel (-2 in the owner field). */
00317   for(i=0; i<k; i++)
00318   {
00319    page_frame_table[i].owner=-2;
00320    page_frame_table[i].free_is_allowed=0;
00321   }
00322 
00323   /* Loop over all the rest page frames and mark them as free (-1 in owner
00324      field). */
00325   for(i=k; i<memory_pages; i++)
00326   {
00327    page_frame_table[i].owner=-1;
00328    page_frame_table[i].free_is_allowed=1;
00329   }
00330 
00331   /* Mark any unusable pages as taken by the kernel. */
00332   for(i=memory_pages; i<MAX_NUMBER_OF_FRAMES; i++)
00333   {
00334    page_frame_table[i].owner=-2;
00335    page_frame_table[i].free_is_allowed=0;
00336   }
00337  }
00338 
00339  /* Go through the linked list of executable images and verify that they
00340     are correct. At the same time build the executable_table. */
00341  {
00342   const struct executable_image* image;
00343 
00344   for (image=ELF_images_start; 0!=image; image=image->next)
00345   {
00346    unsigned long      image_size;
00347 
00348    /* First calculate the size of the image. */
00349    if (0 != image->next)
00350    {
00351     image_size = ((char *) (image->next)) - ((char *) image) -1;
00352    }
00353    else
00354    {
00355     image_size = ((char *) ELF_images_end) - ((char *) image) - 1;
00356    }
00357 
00358    /* Check that the image is an ELF image and that it is of the
00359       right type. */
00360    if (
00361        /* EI_MAG0 - EI_MAG3 have to be 0x7f 'E' 'L' 'F'. */
00362        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_MAG0] != 0x7f) ||
00363        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_MAG1] != 'E') ||
00364        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_MAG2] != 'L') ||
00365        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_MAG3] != 'F') ||
00366        /* Check that the image is a 64-bit image. */
00367        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_CLASS] != 2) ||
00368        /* Check that the image is a little endian image. */
00369        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_DATA] != 1) ||
00370        /* And that the version of the image format is correct. */
00371        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_VERSION] != 1) ||
00372        /* NB: We do not check the ABI or ABI version. We really should
00373           but currently those fields are not set properly by the build
00374           tools. They are both set to zero which means: System V ABI,
00375           third edition. However, the ABI used is clearly not System V :-) */
00376 
00377        /* Check that the image is executable. */
00378        (image->elf_image.e_type != 2) ||
00379        /* Check that the image is executable on AMD64. */
00380        (image->elf_image.e_machine != 0x3e) ||
00381        /* Check that the object format is corrent. */
00382        (image->elf_image.e_version != 1) ||
00383        /* Check that the processor dependent flags are all reset. */
00384        (image->elf_image.e_flags != 0) ||
00385        /* Check that the length of t   he header is what we expect. */
00386        (image->elf_image.e_ehsize != sizeof(struct Elf64_Ehdr)) ||
00387        /* Check that the size of the program header table entry is what
00388           we expect. */
00389        (image->elf_image.e_phentsize != sizeof(struct Elf64_Phdr)) ||
00390        /* Check that the number of entries is reasonable. */
00391        (image->elf_image.e_phnum < 0) ||
00392        (image->elf_image.e_phnum > 8) ||
00393        /* Check that the entry point is within the image. */
00394        (image->elf_image.e_entry < 0) ||
00395        (image->elf_image.e_entry >= image_size) ||
00396        /* Finally, check that the program header table is within the image. */
00397        (image->elf_image.e_phoff > image_size) ||
00398        ((image->elf_image.e_phoff +
00399          image->elf_image.e_phnum * sizeof(struct Elf64_Phdr)) > image_size )
00400       )
00401 
00402    {
00403     /* There is something wrong with the image. */
00404     while (1)
00405     {
00406      kprints("Kernel panic! Corrupt executable image.\n");
00407     }
00408     continue;
00409    }
00410 
00411    /* Now check the program header table. */
00412    {
00413     int                program_header_index;
00414     struct Elf64_Phdr* program_header = ((struct Elf64_Phdr*)
00415                                          (((char*) &(image->elf_image)) +
00416                                           image->elf_image.e_phoff));
00417     unsigned long      memory_footprint_size = 0;
00418 
00419     for (program_header_index = 0;
00420          program_header_index < image->elf_image.e_phnum;
00421          program_header_index++)
00422     {
00423      /* First sanity check the entry. */
00424      if (
00425          /* Check that the segment is a type we can handle. */
00426          (program_header[program_header_index].p_type < 0) ||
00427          (!((program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_NULL) ||
00428             (program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_LOAD) ||
00429             (program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_PHDR))) ||
00430          /* Look more carefully into loadable segments. */
00431          ((program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_LOAD) &&
00432            /* Check if any flags that we can not handle is set. */
00433           (((program_header[program_header_index].p_flags & ~7) != 0) ||
00434            /* Check if sizes and offsets look sane. */
00435            (program_header[program_header_index].p_offset < 0) ||
00436            (program_header[program_header_index].p_vaddr < 0) ||
00437            (program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz < 0) ||
00438            (program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz < 0) ||
00439           /* Check if the segment has an odd size. We require the
00440              segment size to be an even multiple of 8. */
00441            (0 != (program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz&7)) ||
00442            (0 != (program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz&7)) ||
00443            /* Check if the segment goes beyond the image. */
00444            ((program_header[program_header_index].p_offset +
00445              program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz) > image_size)))
00446         )
00447      {
00448       while (1)
00449       {
00450        kprints("Kernel panic! Corrupt segment.\n");
00451       }
00452      }
00453 
00454      /* Check that all PT_LOAD segments are contiguous starting from
00455         address 0. Also, calculate the memory footprint of the image. */
00456      if (program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_LOAD)
00457      {
00458       if (program_header[program_header_index].p_vaddr !=
00459           memory_footprint_size)
00460       {
00461        while (1)
00462        {
00463         kprints("Kernel panic! Executable image has illegal memory layout.\n");
00464        }
00465       }
00466 
00467       memory_footprint_size += program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz;
00468      }
00469     }
00470 
00471     executable_table[executable_table_size].memory_footprint_size =
00472      memory_footprint_size;
00473    }
00474 
00475    executable_table[executable_table_size].elf_image = &(image->elf_image);
00476    executable_table_size += 1;
00477 
00478    kprints("Found an executable image.\n");
00479 
00480    if (executable_table_size >= MAX_NUMBER_OF_PROCESSES)
00481    {
00482     while (1)
00483     {
00484      kprints("Kernel panic! Too many executable images found.\n");
00485     }
00486    }
00487   }
00488  }
00489 
00490  /* Check that actually some executable files are found. Also check that the
00491     thread structure is of the right size. The assembly code will break if it
00492     is not. Finally, initialize memory protection. You will implement memory
00493     protection in task A4. */
00494 
00495  if ((0 >= executable_table_size) ||
00496      (1024 != sizeof(union thread)))
00497  {
00498   while (1)
00499   {
00500    kprints("Kernel panic! Can not boot.\n");
00501   }
00502  }
00503 
00504  initialize_memory_protection();
00505  initialize_ports();
00506  initialize_thread_synchronization();
00507 
00508  /* All sub-systems are now initialized. Kernel areas can now get the right
00509     memory protection. */
00510 
00511  {
00512   /* Use the kernel's ELF header. */
00513   struct Elf32_Phdr* program_header = ((struct Elf32_Phdr*)
00514                                        (((char*) (0x00100000)) +
00515                                         ((struct Elf32_Ehdr*)0x00100000)->
00516                                           e_phoff));
00517 
00518   /* Traverse the program header. */
00519   short              number_of_program_header_entries =
00520                       ((struct Elf32_Ehdr*)0x00100000)->e_phnum;
00521   int                i;
00522   for(i=0; i<number_of_program_header_entries; i++)
00523   {
00524    if (PT_LOAD == program_header[i].p_type)
00525    {
00526     /* Set protection on each segment. */
00527 
00528     update_memory_protection(kernel_page_table_root,
00529                              program_header[i].p_vaddr,
00530                              program_header[i].p_memsz,
00531                              (program_header[i].p_flags&7) | PF_KERNEL);
00532    }
00533   }
00534  }
00535 
00536  /* Start running the first program in the executable table. */
00537 
00538  /* Use the ELF program header table and copy the right portions of the
00539     image to memory. This is done by prepare_process. */
00540 
00541  {
00542   struct prepare_process_return_value prepare_process_ret_val =
00543    prepare_process(executable_table[0].elf_image,
00544                    0,
00545                    executable_table[0].memory_footprint_size);
00546 
00547   if (0 == prepare_process_ret_val.first_instruction_address)
00548   {
00549    while (1)
00550    {
00551     kprints("Kernel panic! Can not start process 0!\n");
00552    }
00553   }
00554 
00555   /* Start executable program 0 as process 0. At this point, there are no
00556      processes so we can just grab entry 0 and use it. */
00557   process_table[0].parent=-1;    /* We put -1 to indicate that there is no
00558                                     parent process. */
00559   process_table[0].threads=1;
00560 
00561   /*  all processes should start with an allocated port with id zero */
00562   if (-1 == allocate_port(0,0))
00563   {
00564    while(1)
00565    {
00566     kprints("Kernel panic! Can not initialize the IPC system!\n");
00567    }
00568   }
00569 
00570   /* Set the page table address. */
00571   process_table[0].page_table_root =
00572    prepare_process_ret_val.page_table_address;
00573   cpu_private_data.page_table_root =
00574    prepare_process_ret_val.page_table_address;
00575 
00576   /* We need a thread. We just take the first one as no threads are running or
00577      have been allocated at this point. */
00578   thread_table[0].data.owner=0;  /* 0 is the index of the first process. */
00579 
00580   /* We reset all flags and enable interrupts */
00581   thread_table[0].data.registers.integer_registers.rflags=0x200;
00582 
00583   /* And set the start address. */
00584   thread_table[0].data.registers.integer_registers.rip =
00585    prepare_process_ret_val.first_instruction_address;
00586 
00587   /* Finally we set the current thread. */
00588   cpu_private_data.thread_index = 0;
00589  }
00590 
00591  /* Set up the timer hardware to generate interrupts 200 times a second. */
00592  outb(0x43, 0x36);
00593  outb(0x40, 78);
00594  outb(0x40, 23);
00595 
00596  /* Now we set up the interrupt controller to allow timer interrupts. */
00597  outb(0x20, 0x11);
00598  outb(0xA0, 0x11);
00599 
00600  outb(0x21, 0x20);
00601  outb(0xA1, 0x28);
00602 
00603  outb(0x21, 1<<2);
00604  outb(0xA1, 2);
00605 
00606  outb(0x21, 1);
00607  outb(0xA1, 1);
00608 
00609  outb(0x21, 0xfe);
00610  outb(0xA1, 0xff);
00611 
00612  kprints("\n\n\nThe kernel has booted!\n\n\n");
00613  /* Now go back to the assembly language code and let the process run. */
00614 }
00615 
00616 /*! Allocate one thread. The allocated thread is not initialized.
00617     Rip and rflags need to be set for the thread to start properly.
00618     \return An index into thread_table or -1 if no thread could be allocated.
00619  */
00620 static inline int
00621 allocate_thread(void)
00622 {
00623  register int i;
00624  /* loop over all threads and find a free thread. */
00625  for(i=0; i<MAX_NUMBER_OF_THREADS; i++)
00626  {
00627   /* An owner index of -1 means that the thread is available. */
00628   if (-1 == thread_table[i].data.owner)
00629   {
00630    return i;
00631   }
00632  }
00633 
00634  /* We return -1 to indicate that there are no available threads. */
00635  return -1;
00636 }
00637 
00638 extern void
00639 system_call_handler(void)
00640 {
00641  register int schedule=0;
00642  /*!< System calls may set this variable to 1. The variable is used as
00643       input to the scheduler to indicate that scheduling is not necessary. */
00644 
00645  /* Reset the interrupt flag indicating that the context of the caller was
00646     saved by the system call routine. */
00647  thread_table[cpu_private_data.thread_index].data.registers.from_interrupt=0;
00648 
00649  switch(SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rax)
00650  {
00651   case SYSCALL_PAUSE:
00652   {
00653    register int  tmp_thread_index;
00654    unsigned long timer_ticks=SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rdi;
00655 
00656    /* Set the return value before doing anything else. We will switch to a new
00657       thread very soon! */
00658    SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rax=ALL_OK;
00659 
00660    if (0 == timer_ticks)
00661    {
00662     /* We should not wait if we are asked to wait for less then one tick. */
00663     break;
00664    }
00665 
00666    /* Get the current thread. */
00667    tmp_thread_index=cpu_private_data.thread_index;
00668 
00669    /* Force a re-schedule. */
00670    schedule=1;
00671 
00672    /* And insert the thread into the timer queue. */
00673 
00674    /* The timer queue is a linked list of threads. The head (first entry)
00675       (thread) in the list has a list_data field that holds the number of
00676       ticks to wait before the thread is made ready. The next entries (threads)
00677       has a list_data field that holds the number of ticks to wait after the
00678       previous thread is made ready. This is called to use a delta-time and
00679       makes the code to test if threads should be made ready very quick. It
00680       also, unfortunately, makes the code that insert code into the queue
00681       rather complex. */
00682 
00683    /* If the queue is empty put the thread as only entry. */
00684    if (-1 == timer_queue_head)
00685    {
00686     thread_table[tmp_thread_index].data.next=-1;
00687     thread_table[tmp_thread_index].data.list_data=timer_ticks;
00688     timer_queue_head=tmp_thread_index;
00689    }
00690    else
00691    {
00692     /* Check if the thread should be made ready before the head of the
00693        previous timer queue. */
00694     register int curr_timer_queue_entry=timer_queue_head;
00695 
00696     if (thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.list_data>timer_ticks)
00697     {
00698      /* If so set it up as the head in the new timer queue. */
00699 
00700      thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.list_data-=timer_ticks;
00701      thread_table[tmp_thread_index].data.next=curr_timer_queue_entry;
00702      thread_table[tmp_thread_index].data.list_data=timer_ticks;
00703      timer_queue_head=tmp_thread_index;
00704     }
00705     else
00706     {
00707      register int prev_timer_queue_entry = curr_timer_queue_entry;
00708 
00709      /* Search until the end of the queue or until we found the right spot. */
00710      while((-1 != thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.next) &&
00711            (timer_ticks>=thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.list_data))
00712      {
00713       timer_ticks-=thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.list_data;
00714       prev_timer_queue_entry=curr_timer_queue_entry;
00715       curr_timer_queue_entry=thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.next;
00716      }
00717 
00718 
00719      if (timer_ticks>=thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.list_data)
00720      {
00721       /* Insert the thread into the queue after the existing entry. */
00722       thread_table[tmp_thread_index].data.next=
00723        thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.next;
00724       thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.next=tmp_thread_index;
00725       thread_table[tmp_thread_index].data.list_data=timer_ticks-
00726        thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.list_data;
00727      }
00728      else
00729      {
00730       /* Insert the thread into the queue before the existing entry. */
00731       thread_table[tmp_thread_index].data.next=
00732        curr_timer_queue_entry;
00733       thread_table[prev_timer_queue_entry].data.next=tmp_thread_index;
00734       thread_table[tmp_thread_index].data.list_data=timer_ticks;
00735       thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.list_data-=timer_ticks;
00736      }
00737     }
00738    }
00739    break;
00740   }
00741 
00742   case SYSCALL_TIME:
00743   {
00744    /* Returns the current system time to the program. */
00745    SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rax=system_time;
00746    break;
00747   }
00748 
00749   case SYSCALL_FREE:
00750   {
00751    SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rax=kfree(SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rdi);
00752    break;
00753   }
00754 
00755   case SYSCALL_ALLOCATE:
00756   {
00757    /* Check the flags. */
00758    if (0!=SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rsi & ~(ALLOCATE_FLAG_READONLY|ALLOCATE_FLAG_EX))
00759    {
00760     /* Return if the flags were not properly set. */
00761     SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rax = ERROR;
00762     break;
00763    }
00764 
00765 
00766    SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rax=kalloc(
00767            SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rdi,
00768            thread_table[cpu_private_data.thread_index].data.owner,
00769            SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rsi & (ALLOCATE_FLAG_READONLY|ALLOCATE_FLAG_EX));
00770    break;
00771   }
00772 
00773   case SYSCALL_ALLOCATEPORT:
00774   {
00775    int port=allocate_port(SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rdi,
00776                           thread_table[cpu_private_data.thread_index].
00777                            data.owner);
00778 
00779    /* Return an error if a port cannot be allocated. */
00780    if (port<0)
00781    {
00782     SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rax=ERROR;
00783     break;
00784    }
00785 
00786    SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rax=port;
00787    break;
00788   }
00789 
00790   case SYSCALL_FINDPORT:
00791   {
00792    int port;
00793    unsigned long process=SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rsi;
00794 
00795    /* Return an error if the process argument is wrong. */
00796    if (process >= MAX_NUMBER_OF_PROCESSES)
00797    {
00798     SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rax=ERROR;
00799     break;
00800    }
00801 
00802    port=find_port(SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rdi,
00803                   process);
00804 
00805    if (port<0)
00806    {
00807     SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rax=ERROR;
00808     break;
00809    }
00810 
00811    SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rax=port;
00812    break;
00813   }
00814 
00815   case SYSCALL_GETPID:
00816   {
00817    SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rax =
00818     thread_table[cpu_private_data.thread_index].data.owner;
00819   break;
00820   }
00821 
00822 
00823 #include "syscall.c"
00824   default:
00825   {
00826    /* No system call defined. */
00827    SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rax=ERROR_ILLEGAL_SYSCALL;
00828   }
00829  }
00830 #include "scheduler.c"
00831 }
00832 
00833 extern void
00834 timer_interrupt_handler(void)
00835 {
00836  /* Increment system time. */
00837  system_time++;
00838 
00839  /* Check if there are any thread that we should make ready.
00840     First check if there are any threads at all in the timer
00841     queue. */
00842  if (-1 != timer_queue_head)
00843  {
00844   /* Then decrement the list_data in the head. */
00845   thread_table[timer_queue_head].data.list_data-=1;
00846 
00847   /* Then remove all elements including with a list_data equal to zero
00848      and insert them into the ready queue. These are the threads that
00849      should be woken up. */
00850   while((-1 != timer_queue_head) &&
00851         /* We remove all entries less than or equal to 0. Equality should be
00852            enough but checking with less than or equal may hide the symptoms
00853            of some bugs and make the system more stable. */
00854         (thread_table[timer_queue_head].data.list_data<=0))
00855   {
00856    register int tmp_thread_index=timer_queue_head;
00857    /* Remove the head element.*/
00858    timer_queue_head=thread_table[tmp_thread_index].data.next;
00859 
00860    /* Let the woken thread run if the CPU is not running any thread. */
00861    if (-1 == cpu_private_data.thread_index)
00862    {
00863     cpu_private_data.thread_index = tmp_thread_index;
00864    }
00865    else
00866    {
00867     /* Or insert it into the ready queue. */
00868     thread_queue_enqueue(&ready_queue, tmp_thread_index);
00869    }
00870   }
00871  }
00872 #include "pscheduler.c"
00873 
00874  /* Acknowledge interrupt so that new interrupts can be sent to the CPU. */
00875  outb(0x20, 0x20);
00876 }
Generated on Thu Apr 8 12:13:51 2010 for 02333 Tasks B6 and A6 by  1.6.3
